lens.book_chapters: Part 2: Heuristics and Biases — Law of Small Numbers, Anchoring, Availability

reinforcements.similarity: Both address monthly-first financial display as the primary anchor. communicates-002 ('Single-Sum Financial Display') prescribes showing one large number in the user's native format (monthly rent for hosts, monthly total for guests) with per-night as derived and secondary. rb-ui-001 ('Monthly-First Search Card') implements this exact prescription on search cards: '$1,760/mo' dominant, '$88/night · 4 nights/wk' secondary. The principle is the same; rb-ui-001 is the search-card instantiation of the pattern communicates-002 defined abstractly.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Design-stack evidence (inside-out): Andreas processes pricing as monthly totals ('Three months. Okay. Got it.'); Shomit says 'I think of this per month and then I break it down per night'; Tapper does manual monthly-to-nightly arithmetic as a workaround. Reverse-benchmark evidence (outside-in): Anyplace's per-night anchoring on all search cards produces sticker shock at checkout; the entire category exploits this anchoring effect; no platform shows monthly-first by default. Two completely independent pipelines — one from user calls, one from competitor analysis — arrive at the same design prescription: monthly total as the primary anchor, per-night as secondary. This is the strongest possible signal.
reinforcements.confidence_boost: Cross-process reinforcement elevates both elements from medium-high to high confidence. communicates-002 already had lens_count:2 from design-stack runs; rb-ui-001 adds a third independent lens from competitor analysis. The monthly-first principle should be treated as a validated platform standard, not a hypothesis.

reinforcements.similarity: looks-003 ('The Single-Number Financial Focal Point') prescribes that every money screen should be dominated by one large figure — the primary financial conclusion — with breakdown available on demand. rb-ui-001 implements this on search cards by making the monthly total the typographically dominant number. The visual specification of rb-ui-001 (Inter 20px/700 for monthly total, Inter 13px/400 for per-night) follows the focal-point hierarchy that looks-003 describes.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: looks-003 was derived from Andreas's call: he processes prices as a single conclusion ('Three months. Got it.') not as a formula. rb-ui-001 was derived from Anyplace's search interface failing users who arrive with a monthly mental model. Both arrive at: one number, large, dominant. The design token alignment is meaningful: both use the same typographic weight hierarchy for financial information.
reinforcements.confidence_boost: looks-003 gets a third-process validation from the reverse-benchmark pipeline. rb-ui-001 inherits the theoretical foundation that looks-003 established in the design-stack runs. Both are strengthened.

reinforcements.similarity: guest-communicates-004 ('Pre-Commitment Rate Anchoring') addresses the same core problem — users anchoring on a single rate that doesn't represent their actual financial commitment — but from a different angle: preventing rate-anchor distortion across seasonal pricing boundaries. rb-ui-001 addresses it at search-card level by correcting the per-night anchor to a monthly anchor. Both are anti-anchoring mechanisms operating at different points in the journey.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: guest-communicates-004 evidence: Nneka's lease spans pricing seasons; Brad anchored on the original rate and experienced seasonal adjustment as betrayal. rb-ui-001 evidence: all Anyplace users anchor on per-night rate and experience monthly total as sticker shock. The shared pattern: users anchor on the first prominent number they see, and any subsequent deviation from that anchor is experienced as a breach of trust, not as a market fact. Together, these two elements define the complete anchoring problem: wrong unit at search (rb-ui-001) and wrong range at evaluation (guest-communicates-004).
reinforcements.confidence_boost: Combined evidence suggests monthly-first pricing must be complemented by seasonal rate display at listing evaluation — these two elements form a complete anti-anchoring system across the search-to-booking funnel.

reinforcements.similarity: communicates-005 ('Pre-Packaged Proposal') prescribes that hosts should modify an existing proposal rather than construct a counter-offer from scratch ('no blank forms for counter-offers'). rb-ui-003 ('Structured Counter-Offer Panel') is the guest-side complement: guests submit a structured counter-offer with a single input, the host receives it in a structured format, and the adjustment history is visible to both. These are two halves of the same bilateral negotiation architecture: communicates-005 describes the host's experience, rb-ui-003 describes the guest's experience.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Design-stack evidence (host-side): Bryant presents a nearly-done arrangement that Andreas can confirm; the platform should make acceptance the default path. Reverse-benchmark evidence (guest-side): Anyplace has no counter-offer mechanism; guests abandon or negotiate informally through agents; Chantel has pre-calculated a 10-15% flexibility window with nowhere to put it. The combined evidence proves: both host and guest want structured negotiation. hosts want to modify a pre-packaged proposal (communicates-005); guests want to propose an alternative rate with a structured input (rb-ui-003). Neither element contradicts the other; they define both sides of the same interaction.
reinforcements.confidence_boost: This is a cross-process validation with unusually strong bilateral evidence: inside-out evidence for the host side, outside-in evidence for the guest side. The combined picture is a negotiation architecture where proposals flow from host (pre-packaged) and guests can counter within a structured range. Implementation should design both elements together as a coherent system.

reinforcements.similarity: guest-behaves-002 ('Date Change Request as a Three-Tap Contextual Flow') prescribes exactly the same interaction as rb-ui-004 ('Night Rescheduling Widget'): embed the date change directly in the Stays Manager, make it faster than texting, auto-calculate rate impact, constrain to available dates, and require host approval. The two elements were developed independently (one from the Nneka call, one from Anyplace's active-stay void) and arrived at the same specification.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Design-stack evidence (inside-out): Brad texts Nneka to reschedule; the platform has no faster alternative; 'He was texting me and saying, Hey, you know, I can't make it for another day.' Reverse-benchmark evidence (outside-in): Anyplace's product is transactionally complete at booking; the entire category offers no active-stay tooling; guests revert to SMS as their primary coordination channel. Two completely independent pipelines arrive at the same solution: an embedded, contextual, three-tap rescheduling widget in the Stays Manager. This is the strongest possible signal for this feature.
reinforcements.confidence_boost: Cross-process convergence at the specification level, not just the principle level. Both elements describe the same interaction model (select night → select new night → confirm with rate auto-calculated), the same technical constraints (host approval required, unavailable dates excluded), and the same design rationale (must be faster than texting). Merging is appropriate: the existing guest-behaves-002 should absorb rb-ui-004's HTML implementation detail.

reinforcements.similarity: guest-works-001 ('Self-Service Date Changes at Conversational Speed') establishes the process-level requirement that rb-ui-004 implements as a UI element. guest-works-001 prescribes: the date change flow must live inside the Stays Manager, must meet guests at their existing context, and must be under 30 seconds. rb-ui-004 implements this with specific interaction specs (3 taps, auto rate calculation, 'Faster than texting' copy).
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Combined: the requirement (guest-works-001) and its implementation (rb-ui-004) are now aligned. The reverse-benchmark provides a second confirmation that the category vacuum for active-stay tooling is real and universal (not just a Split Lease gap but a category gap), elevating the priority of building this feature.
reinforcements.confidence_boost: guest-works-001 gets outside-in validation that the problem it addresses is not unique to Split Lease's users — it is endemic to the entire category. This elevates the element from a user-specific insight to a category-differentiation opportunity.

reinforcements.similarity: communicates-003 ('Trust Credential Stack: Process Before Promise, Verification Before Claim') prescribes the same architecture as rb-ui-005 ('Commitment Confidence Screen'): show verifiable mechanisms first (credit check, ID verification), then the specific instance (this host's record, this guest's status), then the conclusion (this match is ready to confirm). Both use identity verification as the primary trust signal, both show bilateral trust (host-side AND guest-side), and both frame trust as evidence chains rather than marketing badges.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Design-stack evidence (inside-out): Andreas said 'excellent credit on every single tenant' — he trusts mechanisms, not promises; Jessica demanded a confidentiality agreement; Susan asked 'do you do background checks?'; Hemeden insisted on meeting guests. All of these are workarounds for a trust vacuum the platform hasn't filled with specific, verifiable signals. Reverse-benchmark evidence (outside-in): Anyplace shows a generic logo and 4 reviews at checkout for a $4,635 payment; the trust vacuum is universal and exploited by the availability of frightening scenarios. Both pipelines arrive at: trust needs to be specific, bilateral, verifiable, and present at the commitment moment.
reinforcements.confidence_boost: communicates-003 was derived primarily from the host perspective (investor host evaluating tenants). rb-ui-005 adds the guest perspective (evaluating the host at payment) and the bilateral framing (both parties' signals shown simultaneously). The merge should produce a unified bilateral trust architecture element that covers both host and guest commitment moments.

reinforcements.similarity: guest-feels-002 ('The Price Surprise Shield') and rb-ui-007 ('Pricing Transparency Tooltip') both address the same psychological mechanism — preventing anchoring-driven sticker shock — through different implementation layers. guest-feels-002 is an emotional design principle (show original and new rate simultaneously to prevent betrayal). rb-ui-007 is an interactive tooltip that reveals the calculation behind any displayed monthly price. Both are transparency mechanisms that give users the mathematical basis for the price they see.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: guest-feels-002 evidence: Brad anchored on original rate; seasonal adjustment felt like betrayal. rb-ui-007 evidence: Anyplace's per-night anchor forces users to compute the monthly total themselves; even after showing monthly-first prices (rb-ui-001), users in the ghost-roommate model need to understand how 4 nights × 5 weeks = $1,760/month. Combined: pricing transparency is a multi-layer problem. rb-ui-001 gives the correct anchor; rb-ui-007 makes the calculation legible; guest-feels-002 ensures rate changes are disclosed simultaneously rather than sequentially. These three elements are a complete pricing honesty system.
reinforcements.confidence_boost: rb-ui-007 fills the implementation gap between rb-ui-001 (correct anchor) and guest-feels-002 (change disclosure). The trio forms a complete system. Medium confidence — rb-ui-007 is the simplest element and would be validated during rb-ui-001 implementation.

reinforcements.similarity: ds-ui-0900-002 ('Ghost Roommate Guest Profile Card') addresses the host-side anxiety about strangers sharing their space, using progressive disclosure to convert strangers into known people. rb-ui-002 ('Ghost Roommate Model Explainer') addresses the guest-side confusion about the split-stay model, using a three-step visual explanation to convert an unfamiliar model into a compelling one. Both target the representativeness gap — users arriving with wrong mental models — but for different parties.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Design-stack evidence (host-side): Sherene 'I don't like dealing with strangers. And then two strangers that change' — host anxiety about the ghost roommate model. Reverse-benchmark evidence (guest-side): Frederick 'I thought I'd be sharing with the host, I thought it would be like, just me and the other person' — guest confusion about the split-stay model. Both pipelines confirm: the ghost roommate model requires active explanation for both parties. The existing library has the host-side card (ds-ui-0900-002); rb-ui-002 provides the missing guest-side explainer.
reinforcements.confidence_boost: rb-ui-002 fills a clear gap. The library had the host-anxiety solution but not the guest-confusion solution. Both are needed for the ghost roommate model to function. Medium confidence for rb-ui-002 (reverse-benchmark evidence only, no direct guest-confusion transcript yet) elevated by Frederick's call evidence in the crossref layer.

contradictions.conflict: communicates-005 includes an explicit constraint: 'no blank forms for counter-offers' and 'counter-offer form fields on the main proposal view are secondary-path content that clutters the confirmation path.' rb-ui-003 is an entire panel dedicated to the guest's counter-offer form. If communicates-005 is applied literally, the counter-offer panel should not be visible until the host has presented a pre-packaged proposal that the guest explicitly chooses to adjust.
contradictions.evidence_comparison: communicates-005 evidence: Bryan presents the arrangement as nearly done; Andreas's System 2 endorses a suggestion, not constructs a response; depleted hosts default to denial if forced to construct. rb-ui-003 evidence: Chantel has pre-calculated flexibility; negotiation is already happening off-platform through agents; both parties benefit from structured collaborative anchor-setting (Kahneman Ch. 11). The conflict is real: communicates-005 was designed for the HOST acceptance path (not the guest counter-offer path), which is why counter-offer fields clutter the host's view. rb-ui-003 is the GUEST's counter-offer entry point, not the host's confirmation view. The apparent contradiction dissolves on closer reading: they are different views for different users at different moments.
contradictions.recommendation: The contradiction is architectural, not substantive. Resolution: rb-ui-003 should only appear in the guest's proposal flow (after the guest has seen the host's listed price and explicitly taps 'Make a counter-offer'). It must never appear in the host's proposal confirmation view, which is governed by communicates-005. Both constraints are compatible when applied to their respective user flows.

contradictions.conflict: communicates-003 prescribes a maximum of 3 trust signals per screen and explicitly excludes 'aggregate statistics (500+ verified tenants) without specific relevance to the host's current situation.' rb-ui-006 ('Review Confidence Indicator') adds a review sample-size signal inline with every star rating — which is an aggregate statistical signal, not a specific mechanism. The question is whether a confidence arc on '5 reviews' violates communicates-003's principle that trust signals must be specific and mechanism-based.
contradictions.evidence_comparison: communicates-003 evidence: Andreas trusts specific mechanisms ('excellent credit on every single tenant') not statistics. rb-ui-006 evidence: Kahneman's law of small numbers means users cannot spontaneously correct for thin sample sizes; a visual signal is needed to trigger the statistical discount. The conflict reflects a genuine tension: communicates-003 was designed for the host-to-guest trust evaluation (is this specific tenant qualified?), while rb-ui-006 addresses the guest-to-listing trust evaluation (is this review sample statistically reliable?). These are different trust problems.
contradictions.recommendation: No design change required. rb-ui-006 is not a trust credential in communicates-003's sense (it is not vouching for a specific party). It is a statistical transparency tool. communicates-003's 3-signal constraint applies to trust credential stacks (identity, payment, track record), not to statistical metadata displays. The two elements can coexist without conflict.

extensions.gap_filled: No existing library element addresses the law-of-small-numbers problem in review display. The library's trust architecture (communicates-003) addresses bilateral trust credentials but not the statistical reliability of social proof. The library's review-related elements (guest-communicates-007 'Batched Review Prompts') address when and how to collect reviews but not how to display them with appropriate sample-size context. rb-ui-006 is the first element to address statistical honesty in social proof display — a gap that Kahneman's research (Ch. 10) identifies as systematic and important for user decision quality.
extensions.confidence_note: Medium-high confidence. The Kahneman framework support is strong (law of small numbers is extensively documented). The competitive gap is clear (no platform in the category has tried this). The implementation is simple (SVG arc scaled to sample size, tooltip with plain-language explanation). The risk is that users find the 'building confidence' language patronizing — this needs user testing. Reverse-benchmark evidence only; no direct Split Lease user frustration with review reliability has surfaced in the call transcripts reviewed so far.
extensions.needs_design_stack_validation: Yes. The next design-stack run should specifically probe whether guests express uncertainty about review reliability when evaluating listings with thin review counts. If Shomit, Tapper, or other guests can be found saying something equivalent to 'there are only 3 reviews, I'm not sure how much to trust this,' the confidence level should be upgraded to high.

extensions.gap_filled: The library has a host-side ghost roommate explainer (implicit in several ds-ui-0900 elements) but no guest-facing explainer that addresses the model confusion at the listing evaluation stage — before any agent interaction. The representativeness bias fix in the library (guest-feels-006 'The Discovery Promise') prescribes honest expectation-setting at discovery, but does not provide a specific listing-page section that explains the split-stay mechanics visually. rb-ui-002 fills this gap with a concrete, listed-page implementation: three-step process, schedule visualization, and a testimonial that addresses the specific anxieties (cleanliness, pack-up, sharing with a stranger you never meet).
extensions.confidence_note: High confidence on the need (Frederick's call provides direct evidence of guest model-confusion; split-stay is genuinely novel and requires explanation). Medium confidence on the specific implementation (the three-step format and testimonial approach are designed but not yet validated with guest users who arrived confused). The schedule visualization is the strongest element of rb-ui-002 — making the days-of-week calendar legible is the key design problem, and the purple/gray color coding matches the existing design token patterns.
extensions.needs_design_stack_validation: Yes. Specifically: the next guest-facing design-stack run should probe whether the listing-page explainer resolves the model confusion before the agent call, or whether agents continue to spend the first 2-3 minutes of every call explaining the model. If agent time-to-discovery still starts with model explanation after this element is deployed, the element is not working as designed.

extensions.gap_filled: The library has communicates-003 (Trust Credential Stack, host perspective) but no element that specifies what the bilateral trust screen looks like at the guest's commitment moment — the moment of paying $3,000+ to a stranger. The library's trust architecture was developed primarily from the host perspective (Andreas evaluating tenants). rb-ui-005 adds the missing guest perspective: at the Confirm Booking moment, both parties' trust signals should be displayed simultaneously, with the agent vouching for the match, and financial protection terms in plain language. This bilateral framing — host's trust in the guest AND guest's trust in the host, shown at the same moment — is the extension.
extensions.confidence_note: High confidence on the need (Jessica demanded a confidentiality agreement; Susan asked about background checks; Hemeden insisted on meeting guests first — all trust workarounds at the commitment moment). Medium confidence on the bilateral display approach (showing the guest their own trust signals alongside the host's is novel; users may find it confusing that they are being 'evaluated' even as they evaluate the host). The agent photo and vouching quote are the highest-confidence elements of rb-ui-005.
extensions.needs_design_stack_validation: Yes. Specifically: does showing a guest their own verification status (employment confirmed, guest rating 5.0) increase or decrease commitment confidence? The hypothesis is that seeing themselves as a verified, trusted party makes commitment feel safer ('I am also a known quantity'). But it could trigger defensiveness ('why are you showing me my own data?'). User testing required.

extensions.gap_filled: The library has rb-ui-001 (Monthly-First Search Card, from this same run) but no element that makes the monthly calculation legible — especially for the ghost roommate model where the math is genuinely complex (nightly rate × nights per week × average weeks in a month). A user who sees '$1,760/month' on a search card has no immediate way to verify this number from the listed nightly rate without the tooltip. rb-ui-007 fills the 'how was this calculated?' gap that is unique to Split Lease's part-time pricing model.
extensions.confidence_note: Medium confidence. The element is simple (a tooltip), the need is real (the ghost roommate monthly calculation is non-obvious), and it directly supports the brand position of radical pricing honesty established by rb-ui-001. Low implementation risk. The design token alignment with the primary-purple tooltip background matches existing tooltip patterns in the library.
extensions.needs_design_stack_validation: No. This is a complement to rb-ui-001 and can be validated alongside it. If monthly-first pricing (rb-ui-001) works as designed, the tooltip should be the 'how does the math work?' answer that curious users will seek.

cross_process_insights.insight: Monthly-first pricing is confirmed by three independent processes: design-stack (host calls where Andreas thinks monthly), design-stack (guest calls where Shomit, Tapper, and Tom think monthly), and reverse-benchmark (Anyplace exploits per-night anchoring across the entire category). This is the strongest cross-process signal in the library to date.
cross_process_insights.implication: Monthly-first pricing should be treated as a platform standard, not a single feature. Every financial display across the platform — search cards, listing pages, proposal summaries, Stays Manager — should follow the same hierarchy: monthly total dominant, per-night derived and secondary. This is a typographic and information architecture standard, not a feature toggle.

cross_process_insights.insight: The active stay phase is a category-wide void, confirmed by two independent processes: design-stack (Nneka's call shows all mid-stay coordination happens via SMS outside the platform) and reverse-benchmark (Anyplace's product is transactionally complete at booking; the entire category offers no active-stay tooling). This convergence makes the Night Rescheduling Widget / Date Change Three-Tap Flow the most strongly validated feature in this run.
cross_process_insights.implication: The active stay phase is where Split Lease can achieve its largest differentiation from the entire category with relatively small product investment. The rescheduling widget is the beachhead; the broader Stays Manager architecture (guest-works-003) is the moat. Both should be treated as high-priority, high-confidence builds.

cross_process_insights.insight: Trust at the commitment moment is confirmed as the most critical trust gap by two independent processes: design-stack (host workarounds: confidentiality agreements, background check questions, insistence on meeting guests) and reverse-benchmark (guest workarounds: Anyplace users paying $4,635 to a stranger with 4 reviews and a logo). The bilateral trust screen (rb-ui-005) merges with the host-side trust credential stack (communicates-003) to produce a complete bilateral trust architecture.
cross_process_insights.implication: Trust design must be bilateral by default on Split Lease. The platform's ghost-roommate model asks both parties to accept unusual risk (host: stranger in my space on alternating days; guest: paying monthly to an individual homeowner). Trust architecture that addresses only one side produces a product that feels asymmetric. The bilateral trust screen is the platform's signature answer to this asymmetry.

cross_process_insights.insight: Negotiation is already happening off-platform through agents, confirmed by two independent processes: design-stack (Chantel's pre-calculated 10-15% flexibility window; Walaa's agent promising 'I'll negotiate the best price for you') and reverse-benchmark (every mid-term housing platform uses the hotel-checkout UX of fixed prices with no adjustment mechanism). The structured counter-offer panel (rb-ui-003) formalizes what agents already do informally, which is the definition of a well-evidenced platform feature.
cross_process_insights.implication: The counter-offer panel is not speculative product design — it is formalizing a behavior that already occurs at every agent call where a price is discussed. This is the lowest-risk high-value feature in this run: the demand is proven, the agent behavior already models the solution, and no competitor offers it.

cross_process_insights.insight: The ghost roommate model requires explanation at multiple points for different parties (host anxiety about strangers: ds-ui-0900-002; guest confusion about the model: rb-ui-002; the transition handoff anxiety: ds-ui-0900-005). Each of these was developed by a different process looking at a different source, yet they form a coherent model-explanation system.
cross_process_insights.implication: The ghost roommate model explanation is a multi-surface problem: host profile card for the host's view of their guests, listing-page explainer for the guest's first encounter with the model, and handoff tracker for the weekly transition moment. Product design should treat these three elements as a coherent system, not as separate features.

new_tokens_flagged.issue: All 7 new elements use rgb(109, 49, 194) as 'secondary-purple' and #31135D as 'primary-purple'. The design token file (tokens.json) defines accent as #2d5a3d (green) and the primary background palette as warm neutrals (#f6f4f0, #eae7e1). The purple color system used in all new elements is NOT registered in tokens.json — it appears to be the product's evolved color system used in all recent elements but not yet formalized in tokens.json.
new_tokens_flagged.action: tokens.json needs to be updated to reflect the actual color system in use: primary-purple (#31135D), secondary-purple (rgb(109, 49, 194) = #6D31C2), accent-purple (rgb(140, 104, 238) = #8C68EE). The green accent token appears to be a legacy artifact. Recommend updating tokens.json in the next pipeline run to prevent token fragmentation between the spec and the implementation.

new_tokens_flagged.issue: rb-ui-001 uses 'Inter' and 'DM Sans' as typefaces. rb-ui-003 also uses 'Inter' and 'DM Sans'. tokens.json specifies 'Outfit' as the sans typeface and 'Instrument Serif' as the serif. The Inter/DM Sans pairing in recent elements creates a font system split: tokens.json says Outfit, implementations say Inter.
new_tokens_flagged.action: Either update tokens.json to reflect the Inter/DM Sans pairing that all recent elements use, or enforce the Outfit token in new implementations. The current state has the token and the implementation out of sync. This is a token fragmentation risk: future elements that reference tokens.json will use Outfit; elements that reference recent examples will use Inter.

token_compliance.recommendation: tokens.json was established early in the design-stack pipeline (when the product may have used a different color and font system) and has not been updated to reflect the purple color system and Inter/DM Sans typography that all recent elements (both design-stack and reverse-benchmark) use. This is not a new problem introduced by this run — the token gap existed before this run — but it is visible in every element in this batch. Recommend a tokens.json refresh as a maintenance task before the next pipeline run, so that the next round of elements inherits a token system that matches actual implementations.

discovery.source: rb-ui-002 addresses discovery by explaining the ghost roommate model at listing evaluation entry point, which overlaps with late discovery. guest-feels-006 (design-stack) addresses discovery messaging. Coverage is thin because this run focused on competitor flaws at search-and-later phases; the discovery phase (awareness, brand first impression) has not been a reverse-benchmark focus.

evaluation.source: rb-ui-001 (monthly-first search card), rb-ui-006 (review confidence indicator), rb-ui-007 (pricing transparency tooltip). Moderate: pricing and trust signals at evaluation are covered. Schedule compatibility display (guest-looks-006) adds listing card coverage from design-stack. Gap: representativeness bias correction (listing photos vs. residential reality) was identified by Anyplace analysis but has no corresponding UI element yet.

onboarding.source: Not addressed in this run. Onboarding (host or guest account creation, first platform entry) was not a focus of the Anyplace competitor analysis. Design-stack elements cover host onboarding extensively (works-001 through works-004); guest onboarding is thin across all runs.

listing_creation.source: Not addressed in this run. Anyplace's listing creation was not analyzed as a competitor gap in this lens. Design-stack elements cover listing creation (communicates-004, behaves-002) but this run adds nothing to that coverage.

pricing.source: rb-ui-001 (monthly-first search card) and rb-ui-007 (pricing transparency tooltip). These complement existing design-stack pricing elements (communicates-002, looks-003). Pricing transparency now has strong multi-process coverage. Gap: host-side pricing setup (how do hosts set the nightly rate in a way that makes the monthly equivalent legible) is not addressed in this run.

proposal_mgmt.source: rb-ui-003 (structured counter-offer panel) and rb-ui-005 (commitment confidence screen) both operate in the proposal-to-acceptance phase. Combined with existing design-stack elements (communicates-005, guest-behaves-004, guest-communicates-005), proposal management has the most comprehensive library coverage of any phase.

active_lease.source: rb-ui-004 (night rescheduling widget). This run's single active-lease element reinforces and merges with guest-behaves-002. The active lease phase has growing coverage across multiple runs (guest-works-001, guest-works-003, guest-feels-001, rb-ui-0901-001, ds-ui-0900-004, ds-ui-0900-005). Coverage is moderate-to-strong when all runs are counted. The remaining gap is mid-stay proactive communication (no element designs the 'check-in at week 7' touchpoint for multi-month leases).

retention.source: Not addressed in this run. Anyplace's retention void (disappoint-010) was analyzed but no UI element was specified for it in this run's Layer 4. Retention has thin coverage across the library: ds-ui-0900-007 (Cumulative Gift Ledger) covers host-side retention; guest-side retention remains under-addressed.

next_run_recommendations.recommendation: Run a guest-focused design-stack session targeting Frederick's call (model confusion) and any guest transcripts that show review-reliability skepticism. Specifically probe: (1) Do guests express uncertainty about thin review samples? (2) Does the ghost roommate model explanation in rb-ui-002 resolve confusion before the agent call? (3) What language do guests use when they discover seasonal pricing variability?
next_run_recommendations.reason: rb-ui-002 and rb-ui-006 have medium confidence due to reverse-benchmark-only evidence. Guest transcript validation would either confirm these elements at high confidence or reveal that the design approach needs adjustment. Frederick's call is referenced in Layer 2 but has not been the primary lens for any run.

next_run_recommendations.recommendation: Analyze Furnished Finder as the next competitor, using the lens of Ariely behavioral economics (Dan Ariely's predictably irrational pricing patterns). Furnished Finder skews toward long-term rental supply with very different pricing norms. The contrast with Anyplace's professional-photography model would illuminate the trust spectrum between 'too polished' (Anyplace) and 'too raw' (Craigslist-adjacent).
next_run_recommendations.reason: This run identified category-wide anchoring, review, and trust blind spots. Furnished Finder would reveal the other end of the spectrum — what happens when the platform is too honest/raw — and might surface elements addressing the guest's need for a credible mid-point between hotel and Craigslist.

next_run_recommendations.recommendation: Specifically design the mid-stay proactive communication arc — a series of platform-initiated touchpoints calibrated to stay length (day 7 check-in, day 30 milestone, week-before-checkout). Anyplace's analysis (disappoint-006, the Active Stay Void) identified this as a category gap with no competitor addressing it. Split Lease already has more active-stay infrastructure than Anyplace; the next step is proactive communication design.
next_run_recommendations.reason: The active-lease phase has been the most consistently validated gap across all runs (Nneka's call, Anyplace analysis, Sonder analysis in earlier runs). The rescheduling widget (rb-ui-004) addresses reactive active-stay interaction; proactive communication design addresses the preventive side. Together they would make active-lease the most differentiated phase in the platform.

next_run_recommendations.recommendation: Analyze review collection and display systems specifically using a behavioral economics lens focused on availability bias. The post-stay review system was flagged as a category-wide problem (disappoint-007, disappoint-003) but rb-ui-006 only addresses display-side sample-size transparency. A focused competitor analysis of how review systems could capture base-rate data rather than availability-biased narratives (Kahneman Ch. 12) would fill the remaining gap.
next_run_recommendations.reason: The review system is identified as a category blind spot in this run (signature_potential: medium in the competitor analysis). No element in the library addresses structured review collection that captures frequency data ('how many days had an issue?') rather than vivid incident narrative. This is technically addressable but requires a dedicated design effort.

next_run_recommendations.recommendation: Run a retention-focused session specifically designed to produce guest-side retention elements.
